title: 7 Proven Blog Post Templates (That Work Like A Charm)
description: This is a list of 7 detailed blog post templates that are proven to drive traffic to your blog.
content: Blog Post TemplatesWritten by Brian DeanLast updated Jul. 08, 2024This is a list of 7 proven blog post templates. In fact, these templates have helped my blog grow to over 487K unique visitors every month this year. A blog post template simply shows the structure to follow when writing a blog post. Our blog post template eases your approach to writing helpful content for your target audience in a convenient and painless manner. And in this guide, Iâ€™ll give you 7 super detailed content templates that are working great right now. 1. The Classic List Post A list post (also sometimes called a â€œListicleâ€) is a list of 10-25 bite-sized tips, strategies, techniques, toolsâ€¦ or anything else that makes sense for a list. Because they distill a topic into actionable steps, list posts tend to be super search engine friendly. In fact, one of the posts that brings us the most organic traffic every month is a list post: List Post Title Your list post title needs three things: A benefit The number of items A short timeframe First, you need to state the benefit that someone will get out of reading your post. Thereâ€™s no need to be overly creative here. Simply name the benefit. Example: 17 Insanely Actionable List Building Strategies That Will Generate More Subscribers Today (The benefit is: â€œwill generate more subscribersâ€). Next, you need the number of items on your list. If possible, start your title off with that number. Example: 22 Things You Can Do Today to Change Your Photography Forever Finally, you want to demonstrate a specific time frame that shows how actionable your content is. People love strategies they can implement right away. Example: 24 Quick Actions You Can Do Today That Can Change Your Financial Life Forever List Post Introduction Your list post introduction has two parts: An introduction to the problem the reader has The benefit theyâ€™ll get from reading your post First, you quickly (and I mean quickly) introduce the problem that the items on your list will help them solve. Example: I think youâ€™ll agree with me when I say: Itâ€™s REALLY hard to grow a YouTube channel. Second, (quickly!) introduce the benefit that your list post will help them achieve. Good Example: Well, while not as easy as it used to be, you can still get more views and subscribers from your channel. Pro Tip: Donâ€™t forget to really emphasize that your content will help solve the readerâ€™s problem. The more clear that is, the more likely they are to read on. List Post Subheadings Subheadings are HUGE. First, they break your content up into manageable chunks. Second, when you make your subheaders benefit-rich, it boosts the perceived value of your content. So each of your subheadings should contain two things: An overview of what that tip is A clear benefit When people see items that will help them lose weight, eat better or make more money, theyâ€™re more likely to share it. Good Example: Torch Fat With a Protein-Rich Breakfast. Bad Example: Eat Protein at Breakfast Good Example #2: Save $200/Month on Car Insurance With One Phone Call Bad Example #2: Save Money on Car Insurance See the difference? Pro Tip: Make sure you start your ELP off with your best tip. This will hook people for the rest of the post. List Post Action Items Now itâ€™s time to outline the steps someone will need to complete each item on the list. Example: Pro Tip: Include photos, screenshots, real-life examples or even video tutorials. The more visuals you include, the easier it will be for your reader to follow the steps. List Post Conclusion Now itâ€™s time to wrap things up. You want your list post conclusions to do one thing: Push people to take action. When someone gets results from your content, they become a fan for life. Good Example: Pro Tip: Ask your reader to leave a comment. Have them publicly commit to taking action. For example, â€œLet me know the 1 item on this list youâ€™re going to take action on first.â€ 2. The Detailed Case Study A case study is like a traditional how-to postâ€¦ backed up with a real example. Case Study Title To get the most clicks and attention to your case study, your headline should contain 3 elements: Specific Benefit First, state the benefits that the â€œheroâ€ of your case study saw. The more specific, the better. Example: â€œHow a Busy Mom Lost 9 Pounds of Fat in 30 daysâ€ A number Second, you want to include at least one number. This number adds credibility to your case study by showing you have actual data behind your content. Example: â€œLink Building Case Study: How I Increased My Search Traffic by 110% in 14 Daysâ€ Timeframe Finally, specify how long it took to see those benefits. The shorter the time frame the better. Good Example: â€œFrom Geek to Freak: How I Gained 34 lbs. of Muscle in 4 Weeksâ€ Pro Tip: Donâ€™t be afraid to write about modest results in your case study. In fact, modest results are usually BETTER than uber-impressive results. Why? Because theyâ€™re more relatable. In other words, a case study of someone losing 10 pounds is often more compelling than one that describes how someone lost 100 pounds. Case Study Introduction Hereâ€™s what you include in your case study introduction: First, start your intro off with EXACTLY what youâ€™re going to show them in the case study. As the old journalism saying goes: â€œDonâ€™t bury the leadâ€. ğŸ™‚ Example: â€œToday Iâ€™m going to show you how a busy single mom (Jane) dropped 9 pounds of body fat in a month.â€ Next, break down some of the things that make you, your client, friend, or customer relatable. Example: â€œAnd she was able to accomplish this despite the fact that sheâ€™s a busy executive that has very little time to exercise.â€ Finally, preview the solution or system that was used to get this benefit. Then mention youâ€™ll outline how they did it in detail. Example: â€œIn this case study Iâ€™ll show you the entire process that Jane usedâ€¦ step-by-step.â€ Meet The Hero Section The â€œMeet The Heroâ€ section is where you introduce the hero of your case study. This section is important because it helps your reader connect with your hero and put themselves in your heroâ€™s shoes. Quick Introduction of Your Hero Example: â€œJane is a 39-year old mother of two that works as a busy executive at a bank. Her days consist of shuttling kids back and forth to school and soccer practice while answering emails on her phone. Sheâ€™s the consummate super-busy 21st-century mom.â€ Problem Story Example: â€œLike many busy moms, Jane noticed that her jeans were a little more snug than they were a few years back. She knew she should exercise, but with her demanding work schedule and kidâ€™s activities, she didnâ€™t have the time or energy to get to the gym.â€ â€œSave The Cat Momentâ€ The term â€œSave The Catâ€ comes from the screenwriting classic, Save The Cat. Itâ€™s a small detail that makes your hero more human and relatable. Good Example: â€œOne day, after barely being able to button her favorite pair of jeans, Jane realized she needed to do something. So she called her sister, who recently dropped 10 pounds, for advice.â€ Transition to the Case Study Good Example: â€œHer sister referred Jane to me. And now itâ€™s time for me to show you how Jane dropped those excess pounds in record time.â€ Results Section At this point, your reader is anxious to see how they did it. But before diving into the steps, whet their appetite with a quick overview of your heroâ€™s results. Your Results Section subheading should reiterate your heroâ€™s results. Example: â€œHow I Boosted My Conversion Rate by 73.4% (Without A/B Testing)â€ Hereâ€™s what to include in this section: First, quickly outline the results that your Hero achieved. Example: â€œCourtney made an appointment with me on January 3rd. On January 24th, here are her results: 8 pounds of weight loss (120 lbs to 112 lbs) Body fat percentage decrease of 2.1% (down from 30%) Lost 2 dress sizes And her jeans fit better than they have in years :-)â€ Next, include a quick transition to the meat of your case study. This helps the reader understand the story is over and that itâ€™s time to get into the meat of the content. Example: â€œThat afternoon, Jane gave me a call. Hereâ€™s the exact 3-step process she used to lose all that weight.â€ Steps Section Now itâ€™s time to get into the meaty details of your case study. Many case studies are big on hype and short on details. Thatâ€™s why this section is so important. The detailed steps will make your case study stand out. And hereâ€™s where you list the steps your hero used to make progress on Step #1. No detail is too small. Donâ€™t be afraid to tell them EXACTLY what to do. Example: â€œFirst, Jane took note of where she stood with her weight and health. She hopped on the scale to assess her current body weight. Using the fitbit app, she recorded her weight. She weighed 149 poundsâ€¦ Next, Jane got her body fat measured in my office (using bioelectrical impedance). We found her body fat percentage to be 30%, which is considered high for a woman of Janeâ€™s ageâ€¦â€ Note: This is a shortened example. Your final draft should add more details and images like screenshots, diagrams, and pictures. Case Study Conclusion Quick Summary Example: â€œThatâ€™s all there is to it. Thatâ€™s how Courtney lost 9 pounds of fat in just 4 weeks. Motivational Line Hereâ€™s where you remind the reader that they can achieve the same result. Example: â€œThe best part is that you can get the same results Courtney did by following this step-by-step process.â€ Call-To-Action Example: â€œIf you found this case study inspiring, Iâ€™d really appreciate if you would share her story on Facebook. Iâ€™d also like to hear from you: have you used any of these strategies to lose weight? Leave a comment and let me know.â€ And when you finish writing your conclusion, youâ€™re done with your case study. Great work! 3. The Product Showdown This post is a side-by-side comparison of two competing products. Your Product Showdown provides a ton of value. Thatâ€™s because you save your reader countless hours (and dollars) on a product that may not work for them. Product Showdown Title Here are the two things to include in your Product Showdown title: First, the two (or three) products youâ€™re comparing Example: â€œAweber vs. Mailchimpâ€ or â€œWix vs. Squarespaceâ€ Second, note what these products do. In other words, their category. Example: â€œAweber vs. Mailchimp: Two Email Marketing Platforms Comparedâ€ or â€œGNC Fish Oil vs. Optimum Nutrition: We Tested Both Supplementsâ€ Pro Tip: Include the name of both products in your title (for example, â€œAweber vs. Mailchimpâ€). These â€œproduct vs. productâ€ keywords tend to get a ton of searches in Google. Product Showdown Intro (Quick) overview of what your product review post is all about This is straightforward: let people know which products youâ€™re reviewing. This lets your readers know theyâ€™re in the right place. Example: â€œIn this post, Iâ€™m going to personally review two popular email marketing software products: Mailchimp and Aweber.â€ Mention which product features youâ€™re going to evaluate This shows that youâ€™re going to review the products in-depth. This is important because it demonstrates to the reader that you already did the hard work for them. Example: â€œI dove deep into each platform to uncover the good, the bad (and the ugly). Within each platform I evaluated: Cost/value Email deliverability Templates Ease of use Advanced features Autoresponders Customer support and moreâ€ Encourage people to read the entire review Hereâ€™s where you let your readers know that they need to read your entire review to get the whole scoop. Example: â€œSo make sure to read this review until the end. That way you can make the best decision for you.â€ Product Overview Section Overview of each product Example: â€œBefore I get into the review itself, I want to quickly let you know some important info on each platformâ€¦â€ Who you are This is important. Hereâ€™s your opportunity to show people that you have some expertise in this area. Even if youâ€™re not an expert, you can at least tell your story of: â€œhereâ€™s why I tried both productsâ€. Example: â€œBecause I started my WordPress blog on a shoestring budget, I went with MailChimpâ€™s free plan. Overall, I was pretty happy with it. But I quickly realized that Iâ€™d the more advanced features only came with a paid MailChimp accountâ€¦â€ Feature-By-Feature Comparison Hereâ€™s where you begin to break down each feature, one by one (and outline how the two products compare). Example: â€œWho has the better email templates?â€ or â€œWhich supplement has the most omega 3s?â€ Pro Tip: Kick things off with the feature that your readers are most interested in. For example, if you find that your readers want to know which fish oil has the most omega 3 fats, start off with that feature. Product Showdown Conclusion Now itâ€™s time to wrap things up. In many ways, this is the moment your reader has been waiting for. Theyâ€™ve read the feature comparison. Now they want to know which product you recommend. Example: â€œBecause it has a much more robust feature set, better deliverability, and support, I have to go with Aweber. If youâ€™re on an absolute â€œzero budgetâ€ budget, then you might want to start with Mailchimp. But if you have two pennies to rub together, I recommend going with Aweber. As you saw in this review, Aweberâ€™s robust features are worth the slightly higher investment.â€ 4. Things To Do After â€œXâ€ A Things To Do After â€œXâ€ post gives your readers a step-by-step game plan during a critical time. For example, your reader may know how to do kettlebell swings. But what should they do after their workout? Rest? Eat? Stretch? Your Things To Do After â€œXâ€ post answers this question in detail. Things To Do After â€œXâ€ Title The headline for this blog post template should contain two elements: The thing they just did Example: â€œPublishing a blog postâ€ or â€œFinished a power yoga classâ€. The number of tasks they â€œneed to doâ€ when theyâ€™re done Example: â€œ12 Things You Need to Do After You Publish a Blog Postâ€ or â€œ13 Important Steps After Youâ€™ve Finished Your Power Yoga Workoutâ€ Things To Do After â€œXâ€ Introduction Your Things To Do After â€œXâ€ intro contains four elements: A visualization of the thing they just did Example: â€œSo you just finished your power yoga workout. Youâ€™re tired. Youâ€™re sweaty. And you feel energized and focused.â€ Raise the question: â€œNow what?â€ Example: â€œBut the question is: What should you do next?â€ Mention possibilities of what they could do Example: â€œShould you eat a â€˜recovery mealâ€™? Should you stretch? Or is it better to spend some time on the couch?â€ Promise youâ€™ll show them how itâ€™s done Example: â€œAnd in todayâ€™s post, Iâ€™m going to show you the 13 most important steps to take after you finish with your power yoga class (step-by-step).â€ Steps Section Now itâ€™s time to dive right into the items on your list. And your subheader should clearly state what your reader needs to do. Each step in your Things To Do After â€œXâ€ list contains 3 elements. Brief overview Before you dive into the step-by-step detail, itâ€™s time to write a quick (50-90 word) overview of each step. This overview gives context to the item and shows people exactly why itâ€™s important. Example: â€œMany rookie bloggers think that sharing their blog post on Twitter and Facebook is enough. But you know that content today requires much more promotion. Specifically, you need to promote your post with email outreach.â€ Pro Tip: Try to write this overview in their own words. You can look at forums, Reddit and old emails to see how your readers and customers describe their problems. Specific steps Hereâ€™s where you list the steps your reader will need to take to complete the task. Example: â€œStep #1: Identify 5 people that would enjoy reading your post. Ideally these are people that you know in real life (or even just online). If no one comes to mind, Google your keyword and see what blogs come up. These bloggers make ideal targets for your outreach. Step #2: If you donâ€™t know their email addresses, use a tool like Rapportive to find them. Step #3: Send each of these peeps this exact script:â€ Things To Do After â€œXâ€ Conclusion Reminder that what you do â€œafterâ€ is really important Example: â€œWe all know that publishing great content is your blogâ€™s foundation. However, your great content is likely to be invisible unless you take the time to promote it after you hit the â€˜publishâ€™ button.â€ Highlight a few of the best tips from your post Example: â€œThatâ€™s why the tips from this post â€” like creating a custom image for social media and replying to every comment â€” are so powerful. CTA Example: â€œNow I want to hear from you: How are you going to change what you do after you hit â€˜publishâ€™? Are you going to create custom images or email 5 people?â€ 5. The Beginnerâ€™s Guide The Beginnerâ€™s guide is one of my favorite blog post templates. This template helps eliminate overwhelm by showing your readers the exact first steps to get started. In fact, because theyâ€™re so valuable, Beginnerâ€™s Guides tend to attract a ton of backlinks and social media shares. The Beginnerâ€™s Guide Title Your Beginnerâ€™s guide title should contain the topic youâ€™re covering and the words â€œBeginnerâ€™s Guideâ€. Example: â€œThe Beginnerâ€™s Guide to Interval Trainingâ€ or â€œLink Building: The Beginnerâ€™s Guideâ€. Pro Tip: Donâ€™t be afraid to pick a super-specific topic when using this blog template. People love to read guides that are â€œan inch wide and a mile deepâ€. For example, instead of â€œThe Beginnerâ€™s Guide to Gardeningâ€ go with â€œThe Beginnerâ€™s Guide to Growing Tomatoesâ€. The Beginnerâ€™s Guide Introduction A â€œpromise statementâ€ First, hit your reader off with a â€œpromise statementâ€ of the benefit theyâ€™ll get from reading your blog post. Example: Today Iâ€™m going to show you how to grow a brand new blog from scratch.â€ Outline how complex the topic can be Next, show your reader that you understand how hard this topic is to learn. This will show you understand where theyâ€™re coming from. Example: â€œI remember when I first started to learn about SEO. Iâ€™d go from blog post to forum thread trying to understand how SEO actually worked. It was super confusing and frustrating.â€ A preview of whatâ€™s to come Finally, preview the awesomeness thatâ€™s coming up. Example: â€œAnd in this no-nonsense guide Iâ€™ll cut out all the noise and BS and show you exactly how to start building links to your website.â€ The Topic Overview Now itâ€™s time to explain exactly what the topic youâ€™re covering is all about. Donâ€™t be afraid to really dumb things down here (this is a beginnerâ€™s guide after all). A simple definition Example: â€œWhat is link building, exactly?â€ Link building is the process of creating links from other sites to your site. Itâ€™s important because links are the #1 ranking factor that Google uses to rank websites.â€ An example (or two) Example: â€œFor example, letâ€™s say you have a page on your site about baking low-carb cookies. How does Google know that your page deserves to rank above the thousands of other pages on that same topic? Backlinks. And when you build links from other related sites to your low-carb cookie page, Google will rank it higher in their search results.â€ Transition to the next section Example: â€œNow that you understand what link building is, itâ€™s time for me to explain more about how to get started with it.â€ Steps Section Hereâ€™s where you walk your readers through the first few critical steps to get them on their way. These steps may not get them all the way to their goal, but theyâ€™ll point them in the right direction. Brief overview of the step Good Example: â€œYour first step with link building is actually to create something worth linking to on your own site. Because the fact is, unless you have a piece of awesome content on your site, itâ€™s going to be impossible to build the type of high-quality links that you need to rank in Google.â€ Good Example: â€œHereâ€™s exactly how to do it: First, do a Google search for your target keyword. Keep an eye out for pieces of content that impress you. If you donâ€™t see any great pieces of content, try a few different keywords that are similar to the one you just searched for. Next, take a look at all of the top 10 results. Note what makes them great and worthy of a first-page ranking. Is it the fact that they use a lot of examples? Is the page well-written? Are there step-by-step processes in the content? Also, see what types of blog posts (or other content) tend to rank for your target keyword. Are they: List posts Ultimate guides Case studies â€œBest ofâ€ lists Finally, plan your piece of content based on what you found. Make sure to improve on the content thatâ€™s already ranking above you â€“that way your content deserves to be #1. For example, if most of the content on Googleâ€™s first page are lists posts with 10-15 items, do 25 (or even 50). Or do 15 but add more detailed info for each item. This takes some work, but itâ€™s the only way to build quality backlinks today.â€ Transition to next step Good Example: â€œAt this point you have an awesome piece of content on your site. Next, weâ€™ll start our hunt for places that you can get links from.â€ Rinse and repeat this formula for as many steps as you need for your beginnerâ€™s guide. Beginnerâ€™s Guide Conclusion Reminder of how helpful your guide is Example: â€œThanks to â€˜Link Building: The Beginnerâ€™s Guideâ€™, you donâ€™t need to spend hours searching for link building information anymore. You have everything you need to get started all in one place.â€ Reiterate how important your topic is Example: â€œAs you saw in the guide, link building can make or break your SEO efforts. Without link building, your chances of ranking in Google is almost zero. But when you build links the right way you can quickly leapfrog your competition on Googleâ€™s first page.â€ CTA Example: â€œNow you have everything you need to get started with link building. Before you start on your first link, make sure to leave a quick comment to let me know what you think of â€˜Link Building: The Beginnerâ€™s Guideâ€™.â€ 6. How They Did It Post A â€œHow They Did Itâ€ Post shines light on how successful people or groups achieved amazing results. These posts are great because you reveal â€œthe secretâ€ behind their success â€“and show your reader how they can achieve similar results. How They Did It Post Headline Here are the three elements to include in your â€œHow They Did Itâ€ Post headline: The successful people or organization youâ€™re going to focus on. Good Example: â€œFast-Growing Startupsâ€ or â€œWorldâ€™s Most Successful Bodybuildersâ€ The number of people or organizations youâ€™ll cover. Good Example: â€œ12 Fast-Growing Startupsâ€ or â€œ15 of the Worldâ€™s Most Successful Bodybuildersâ€ What the reader will learn from your post. Good Example: â€œWhat These 12 Fast-Growing Startups Can Teach You About Email Marketingâ€ or â€œ15 of the Worldâ€™s Most Successful Bodybuilders Reveal Their Post-Workout Regimenâ€. How They Did It Post Intro Overview of the opportunity Hereâ€™s where you emphasize that thereâ€™s lots of opportunity for success in this area â€“assuming you know how to do it. Example: â€œWeâ€™ve all heard stories about â€œUnicornâ€ startups that explode onto the scene with millions of users. But what you may not know is that every startup has the potential for this type of growth. That is if they leverage email marketing the right way.â€ Emphasize that certain people and groups excel where others fail This paints a clear picture that thereâ€™s a right way (and a wrong way) to approach things. Example: â€œUnfortunately, not all startups go from â€œ3 guys in a garageâ€ to â€œ250 people in a San Francisco loft officeâ€ overnight. In fact, according to Bloomberg, 80% of startups fail within the first 18 months. But not everyone struggles. Startups like Uber have defied the odds and exceeded all expectations of reasonable growth. The question is: how can you avoid failing and emulate the growth of Silicon Valleyâ€™s hottest startups?â€ Show your reader that youâ€™ll reveal the secret to their success Finally, promise them that youâ€™ll show them the path to success based on real-world examples. Example: In this post Iâ€™m going to show you how the most successful startups in the world â€” like Slack, Spotify and Uber â€” leverage email marketing to grow their companies in record time. Strategies Section Now itâ€™s time to outline the strategies they used to achieve their impressive results. Brief overview of the person or groupâ€™s success Outline a few statistics to prove this person or group is a super-successful outlier. This will motivate your reader to learn how they achieved these impressive results. Example: â€œAirbnb started in 2008 as three guys that wanted to rent out their living room to travelers. Today Airbnb hosts one million guests per night. Not to mention a valuation of 20 billion dollars.â€ Their unique approach Outline what they do thatâ€™s unique or different. Example: â€œLike any massive success story, there are hundreds of factors that led to Airbnbâ€™s success. But one of the most important is Airbnbâ€™s approach to email marketing. Instead of boring newsletters or â€œone-size-fits-allâ€ email blasts, Airbnb tailors their emails to what youâ€™re interested in.â€ Why it works Example: â€œHereâ€™s why this approach works so well: In sharp contrast to sending a 10% off coupon to people that abandon shopping carts, Airbnb is sending you more information on that city. That way you can make a decision thatâ€™s right for you. In Airbnb parlance, this soft sell is known as â€œinspirationâ€. How to apply it Example: â€œHereâ€™s how you can apply this approach to your email marketing. First, laser target your emails. Most email service providers (like Aweber and InfusionSoft) allow you to send emails based on behavior. For example, if someone clicks on a link in an email about low carb desserts, make sure that the next email they get is about low-carb recipes or meal plansâ€¦â€ How They Did It Post Conclusion Youâ€™ve given your audience a ton of actionable tips based on real-world examples. Now itâ€™s time to encourage them to take action. Re-iterate that these tips are backed by actual experience Remind your readers one last time that your advice is unique and battle-tested in the real world. Example: â€œThatâ€™s how 21 insanely-successful startups use email marketing to get more users and customers. The best part about using their approach is that itâ€™s not based on theory â€“itâ€™s proven to work in the real world.â€ Encourage your reader to take action Push the reader to use your advice and make a public commitment by leaving a comment. Example: â€œNow that youâ€™ve seen how well these email marketing tips work, itâ€™s time to carve out some time to put at least one of these tips into practice soon. Also, which of the approaches are you most excited to try first? Let me know by leaving a quick comment below.â€ 7. The Myth Debunker Our last blog template is â€œThe Myth Debunkerâ€. Why does this template work so well? Two reasons: First, when you dispel common myths, you drum up controversy. Controversy pushes people that agree (and disagree) with you to share your content. Also, when you round up a bunch of â€œbest practicesâ€, and prove that theyâ€™re myths, you show off your knowledge and expertise. The Myth Debunker Title You have two options with your Myth Debunker title: Highlight a single myth: â€œThe ____ Myth Debunked (Plus 5 More ____ Myths That Drive Me Nuts)â€ Or Outline the number (and type) of myths youâ€™re going to cover: â€œ13 ____ Myths That Every ____ Should Knowâ€ Example: â€œ13 Search Engine Optimization Myths That Every Online Business Owner Needs to Knowâ€ The Myth Debunker Intro Like the other blog post templates we covered in this guide, the #1 goal of your Myth Debunker intro is to grab your readerâ€™s attention. Specifically, you want to let them know theyâ€™re about to learn the truth about your topic. Attention grabber Your first few lines should grab your readerâ€™s attention. Specifically, highlight one common myth in your industry. Example: â€œIf you think that SEO is as simple as â€˜publishing great content on a regular basis, then Iâ€™ve got news for you: that advice is completely wrong.â€ Pro Tip: Donâ€™t be afraid to show some emotion here. Let your reader know that these myths really get under your skin. This will help you form an emotional bond that turns your â€œreaderâ€ into a â€œfollowerâ€. Promise to show your reader the real deal Preview whatâ€™s coming next. Also, highlight the fact that your post will be based on dataâ€¦ not hunches or opinions. Good Example: â€œIn todayâ€™s post, Iâ€™m going to show you the TRUTH about SEO. Not only will I reveal the 11 most common SEO myths on the planet, but Iâ€™ll show you new data from industry studies that can help you get on the right track.â€ Myths Section Hereâ€™s where you highlight (and break down) common myths in your space. 1. Background on the myth Give your reader context on how this myth came to be. Example: â€œBack in the early days of blogging and SEO, publishing content on a regular basis did work. Which is why this approach to content creation got so popularâ€. 2. Data or case study Now itâ€™s time to show your reader why this concept is a mythâ€¦ and prove it with data. Example: â€œHowever, fresh content isnâ€™t as effective as it used to be. The main reason? Thereâ€™s more content out there than ever before. So to grow your blog today, you canâ€™t just publish a bunch of content. You need to publish epic stuff (like in-depth case studies and infographics). In fact, I grew my blog to over 5,000 visitors per month with only 11 total pieces of blog content.â€ 3. Why the myth is a myth Youâ€™ve shown them the evidence. Now itâ€™s time to explain why the myth is a myth. Example: â€œHow did I grow my blog with 11 posts while other blogs struggled to take off. Hereâ€™s the explanationâ€¦â€ 4. What to do instead Example: â€œSo if youâ€™re looking for an alternative to publishing a new post every week, hereâ€™s the approach that I recommend trying outâ€¦â€ The Myth Buster Conclusion Recap of the most surprising myths Example: â€œThere you have it: 11 SEO and blogging myths. You may not have realized that publishing content on a regular basis doesnâ€™t work like it used to.â€ Reiterate that you showed them the truth (with data) Example: â€œBut as you saw, content marketing is now more about quality. Not quantity.â€ Call to action Example: â€œNow I want to turn it over to you: Which of these myths did you find most surprising?â€
